Key Arguments: The proposed Bill lacks comprehensive definitions for misinformation and disinformation, leading to potentially arbitrary decisions by ACMA.
The terms misinformation and disinformation are seen as tools to suppress free speech and open thought, which are fundamental to democracy.
The Bill could infringe on political rights and duties, potentially violating existing laws that protect these rights.
The immediacy and breadth of information on the internet should be accepted by governments, even if it is controversial.
Personal experience of censorship on platforms like Facebook is cited as an example of potential overreach and suppression of political expression.
Notable Quotes: I regard this proposed Bill as an absolute outrage, in that this Bill lacks comprehensive detail as to any definitions as to what the proposed ACMA body might regard as misinformation and disinformation.
This Bill is the Thought Police legislated, and has no place in any alleged Democracy.
No suppression of serious political debate should be entertained, especially by government.
